title: The Score Neutrality Movement
outcome: Stenograd’s residents, reeling from inexplicable reversals in their BCI status, begin to reject BCI-based privileges entirely. Service workers, teachers, and transit operators enact 'score-blind' policies, treating all citizens equally regardless of BCI status. Oksana Lintz offers cautious support, turning public opinion toward reform. The Directorate responds with threats and scattered crackdowns, but the movement spreads. The BCI’s role as silent enforcer is openly challenged for the first time, shifting the city’s center of authority to everyday acts of defiance.

events.description: Groups of service workers collectively refuse to check BCI scores, demanding universal access to city resources and jobs.
Lintz endorses experiments in 'score-blind' service zones, gaining support among teachers and health staff. Directorate leadership voices alarm.
Several districts enact full score-neutrality policies, allowing all residents free movement and employment on a trial basis.
Directorate loyalists attempt to reimpose BCI restrictions in key sectors, leading to public standoffs and viral images of resistance.
A wave of public endorsements and rallies cement score neutrality as a mainstream demand. For the first time, open rejection of the BCI system becomes the new center of political power.
